fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Senior Lecturer in Computer Science.
\mu HOL^{ex} is a logic and cyclic proof system that I've been developing for part of my PhD project with my supervisor Reuben Rowe.

The goal is to develop a proof system for higher-order logic with fixed-point operators, that allows for induction and coinduction by adding fixed-point "unfolding" rules, and allowing proofs to be cyclic.
PhD student at Royal Holloway, University of London researching programming language semantics via cyclic proof theory, type theory, and category theory. Supervised by Reuben Rowe.
Reuben and I discussed methods of allowing \forall -reductions to work in \mu HOL^{ex}.

fr:title.text: Ideas for cycle reduction in HOL^{ex}

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Ideas for cycle reduction in \mu HOL^{ex}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We are (still) working out how we can equip cycles with a notion of reduction or "unfolding". We specifically want the property that we can "unfold" a cycle and then replace a free variable along the cycle with some term without breaking the well-formedness of the cycle: lets call this property A.

We've found a criteria that the substitutions along cycles have to satisfy to allow us to "unfold" them in a way that has property A - that is the requirement that each variable is either substituted by itself or a fresh variable w.r.t. the companion sequent. Call this property P. P(\theta , B, C) := \forall x \in \text {fv}(C) . \theta (x) = x \vee \theta (x) \notin \text {fv}(C) If this holds, then we can "unfold" the cycle just once and the resulting proof has property A. If this doesn't hold, the current idea is to translate the proof to a different one where the cycle in question has property P.
The translation revolves around the idea of replacing \mu -formulae with semantically equivalent ones that interact with the free variables of the sequent in subtle way.

We could require that substitution property P holds of all cycles for a proof to be valid. However, it's clear that adopting this may lead to reductions getting stuck; it may be the case that perfoming a reduction invalidates the property.

Hence if we adopt this approach, we should also characterise which proofs will not get stuck. This is probably something like those that satisfy the property P when they are r-normal for all reductions r \neq \text {fix}. For the proofs that don't get stuck, we should be able to prove some sort of normalisation result.
Entailments in \mu HOL^{ex} can be constructed with the following natural deduction style inference rules.

The (capture-avoiding) substitution of an expression t' for a variable x in the expression t, denoted by t[t'/x], is defined inductively as follows.
 egin {align*} y[t'/x] &= t' &	ext {if } y = x\ y[t'/x] &= y &	ext {if } y 
eq x\ (\alpha <  eta )[t'/x] &= \alpha <  eta \ (t_1\ t_2)[t'/x] &= t_1[t'/x]\ t_2[t'/x]\ (t_1 \Rightarrow t_2)[t'/x] &= t_1[t'/x] \Rightarrow t_2[t'/x]\ (\lambda (y^v: T).t)[t'/x] &= \lambda (y^v: T).t[t'/x] &	ext {if } y 
eq x 	ext { and } y 
otin 	ext {fv}(t')\ ( orall (y: T).t)[t'/x] &=  orall (y : T).t[t'/x] &	ext {if } y 
eq x 	ext { and } y 
otin 	ext {fv}(t')\ (\mu ^\alpha (y : P).t)[t'/x] &= \mu ^\alpha (y : P).t[t'/x] &	ext {if } y 
eq x 	ext { and } y 
otin 	ext {fv}(t')\ (\exists \alpha .t)[t'/x] &= \exists \alpha .t[t'/x] \end {align*}
Simple type environments, denoted \mathcal {H}, are finite partial maps from expression variables to tuples of a variance annotation and a domain.

When \mathcal {H}(x) is undefined for all x we say \mathcal {H} is empty. Abusing notation, we write x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} to mean \mathcal {H}(x) = (v , T), and \mathcal {H} \subseteq \mathcal {H}^\prime to mean that x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} implies x^v : T \in \mathcal {H}^\prime .
Simple type environments, denoted \mathcal {H}, are finite partial maps from expression variables to tuples of a variance annotation and a domain.

When \mathcal {H}(x) is undefined for all x we say \mathcal {H} is empty. Abusing notation, we write x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} to mean \mathcal {H}(x) = (v , T), and \mathcal {H} \subseteq \mathcal {H}^\prime to mean that x^v : T \in \mathcal {H} implies x^v : T \in \mathcal {H}^\prime .
For all simple type environments we have (\mathcal {H}^-)^- = \mathcal {H}.

fr:title.text: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For all simple type environments we have \mathcal {H}_1 \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2 if and only if \mathcal {H}_1^- \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2^-.
For all simple type environments we have (\mathcal {H}^-)^- = \mathcal {H}.

fr:title.text: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Simple type environment negation preserves inclusion

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For all simple type environments we have \mathcal {H}_1 \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2 if and only if \mathcal {H}_1^- \subseteq \mathcal {H}_2^-.
